Zhejiang, China. State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials School of Materials Science and Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou Zhejiang 310027 China Magnesium hydride has been seen as a potential material for solid state hydrogen storage, but the kinetics and thermodynamics obstacles have hindered its development and application. Three-dimensional flower-like TiO2@C and TiO2 were synthesized as the catalyst for MgH2 system and great catalytic activities are acquired in the hydrogen sorption properties. Experiments also show that the flower-like TiO2@C is superior to flower-like TiO2 in improving the hydrogen storage properties of MgH2. The hydrogen desorption onset and peak temperatures of flower-like TiO2 doped MgH2 is reduced to 199.2 °C and 245.4 °C, while the primitive MgH2 starts to release hydrogen at 294.6 °C and the rapid dehydrogenation temperature is even as high as 362.6 °C. The onset and peak temperatures of flower-like TiO2@C doped MgH2 are further reduced to 180.3 °C and 233.0 °C. The flower-like TiO2@C doped MgH2 composite can release 6.0 wt% hydrogen at 250 °C within 7 min, and 4.86 wt% hydrogen at 225 °C within 60 min, while flower-like TiO2 doped MgH2 can release 6.0 wt% hydrogen at 250 °C within 8 min, and 3.89 wt% hydrogen at 225 °C within 60 min. Hydrogen absorption kinetics is also improved dramatically. Moreover, compared with primitive MgH2 and the flower-like TiO2 doped MgH2, the activation energy of flower-like TiO2@C doped MgH2 is significantly decreased to 67.10 kJ/mol. All the improvement of hydrogen sorption properties can be ascribed to the flower-like structure and the two-phase coexistence of TiO2 and amorphous carbon. Such phase composition and unique structure are proved to be the critical factor to improve the hydrogen sorption properties of MgH2, which can be considered as the new prospect for improving the kinetics of light-metal hydrogen storage materials. Graphical abstract Three-dimensional flower-like TiO2@C was synthesized as the catalyst for MgH2 system and great catalytic activities are acquired in the hydrogen sorption properties. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrogen storage Magnesium hydride TiO2 Flower-like structure Catalytic effects 1 Introduction Hydrogen as a clean and renewable energy resource has been considered as one of the ideal energy carriers for the mobile devices. But there are still some technological challenges hindering the practical application of hydrogen energy [1–3]. Developing a safe and efficient hydrogen storage facility is one of the major tasks for hydrogen economy. In the past few years, effort has been made to seek the perfect materials for hydrogen storage in solid state [4]. Among all the hydrogen storage materials in solid state, magnesium hydride exhibits high gravimetric hydrogen density (7.6 wt%) and excellent reversibility [5–10]. However the high operational temperature and the kinetic obstacle limit its practical application. To overcome this problem, catalyst doping has been demonstrated to be much effective for enhancing the de/hydrogenation kinetics, thus reducing the hydrogen desorption temperature [11–15]. Transition metal compound is one of the common catalysts in improving the kinetics of MgH2 [16–24]. And the morphology or structure of different catalysts is comparatively important to achieve the catalytic effect. Zhang et al. designed a core-shell Ni3N@nitrogen-doped carbon structure and doped into MgH2 system. The onset desorption temperature of MgH2-5 wt%Ni3N@NC composites decreased to 175 °C compared to the pure MgH2 (335 °C) [25]. Wang et al. created a core–shell Co@C catalyst for enhancing the hydrogen sorption properties of MgH2 [26]. And the MgH2–10%Co@C sample starts to release hydrogen at 168 °C and about 6.00 wt% hydrogen is released during its decomposition. The activation energy of MgH2–10%Co@C is determined to be 84.5 kJ mol−1. Jardim et al. synthesized several titanates and niobates with one-dimensional structure, and proved the catalytic effect of different morphology [27–29]. Liu et al. added a 2D Ti3C2 material obtained by the exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 into the MgH2 system via ball milling method [30]. And the catalyst doped MgH2 shows great hydrogen de/absorption properties. In our previous work, several titanates with one-dimensional tubular or rod-like structure were synthesized and had been proved efficient for the hydrogen storage properties in MgH2 system [22,23]. Meanwhile a two-dimensional TiO2 nanosheet with exposed {001} facets was successful synthesized and the TiO2 nanosheet shows better improvement in hydrogen sorption kinetics of MgH2 than TiO2 nanoparticles [31]. It can be concluded that the morphology and structure of catalysts are important for the catalytic effect in MgH2 system. Base on the above analyses, three-dimensional flower-like TiO2 (fl-TiO2) and flower-like carbon wrapped TiO2 (fl-TiO2@C) were designed and doped into MgH2 system by mechanical milling. The three-dimensional flower-like carbon wrapped TiO2 exhibits a great catalytic activity on the hydrogen de/absorption performance. The hydrogen storage properties and reaction mechanism of the catalyst doped MgH2 have been investigated and discussed in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of 3D flower-like titanium glycerolate precursor The 3D flower-like titanium glycerolate was synthesized according to the reported method [32]. In brief, 2 mL tetrabutyl titanate (Ti(OBu)4, 98.0%, aladdin) was injected in to the mixture of 10 mL glycerol (≥99.0%, Sinopharm) and 30 mL ethanol (≥99.7%, Sinopharm) under magnetic stirring. After stirring for 10 min, the clear solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 24 h. Then the products were filtered, washed with ethanol and dried at 80 °C overnight. The white powder identified as the titanium glycerolate precursor was obtained. 2.2 Synthesis of 3D flower-like TiO2 and flower-like carbon wrapped TiO2 To synthesize the 3D flower-like TiO2 and flower-like carbon wrapped TiO2, the titanium glycerolate precursor was annealed at 450 °C under different reaction atmospheres (air, Ar) for 3 h. The resulting black (in Ar) and white (in air) powders were collected and marked as fl-TiO2@C and fl-TiO2 for further analysis and synthesis. 2.3 Synthesis of TiO2 catalyzed MgH2 Catalyzed MgH2 was synthesized using the ball milling method. 3D fl-TiO2 and fl-TiO2@C were mixed with MgH2 with a weight ratio of 5:95. Then the mixture was milled under 2 MPa hydrogen for 4 h in a planetary ball mill (QM-3SP4, Nanjing). All the sample handing was performed in an Ar-filled glovebox (Mikrouna) with < 1 ppm O2 and H2O vapor levels. 2.4 Characterization The phase composition was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on an X'Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer (PANalytical, the Netherlands) with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. The morphology and elemental distribution of the samples were examined with a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX, HORIBAX-Max). Scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU-70) was also used to determine the morphology of the different catalysts. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were conducted on a Netzsch STA449F3 analyzer under high purity flowing argon conditions. The hydrogen sorption of all the samples was examined in a carefully calibrated Sievert's type apparatus. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The phase and morphology of the as-synthesized 3D fl-TiO2 and fl-TiO2@C Fig. 1 (a) shows the XRD patterns of titanium glycerolate precursor, the diffraction peaks mainly concentrate at the low angle region. And the peak positions are corresponding to reported literature data [32]. Fig. 1(b) is the XRD pattern of fl-TiO2@C obtained from carbonizing the glycerolate precursor at 450 °C under Ar flow condition. The primary diffraction peaks can be ascribed to the anatase phase of TiO2 and small peak of rutile TiO2 can also be identified at around 27.4°. The coexistence of both TiO2 phases is because of the wide temperature range for the phase transformation of TiO2. And there is no distinct diffraction peak of carbon in the XRD pattern which indicates that carbon in this material is at amorphous state. The XRD pattern of fl-TiO2 is shown in Fig. 1(c). The strong diffraction peaks can be ascribed to the anatase TiO2. Also small diffraction of rutile TiO2 can be detected. Meanwhile the diffraction peaks of TiO2 can be found significantly enhanced comparing to the fl-TiO2@C sample. This difference is due to the grain growth of TiO2 during heat treatment. 3D flower-like TiO2 and TiO2@C were synthesized though carbonizing the titanium glycerolate precursor with flower-like structure. Fig. 2 (a) and (b) is the typical SEM images of 3D flower-like titanium glycerolate precursor under different magnification. From the SEM images, 3D flower-like structure of titanium glycerolate with an average diameter of ~2 µm can be observed. The flower-like structure is composed of numerous short rod rather than sheet structure. Fig. 2(c and d) presents the SEM images of 3D fl-TiO2@C and fl-TiO2. It is clear that the morphology of precursor was completely preserved after heat treatment. 3.2 Catalytic effect of 3D fl-TiO2 and TiO2@C in the hydrogen storage properties of MgH2 To investigate the catalytic effect of the as-synthesized TiO2 on MgH2, 3D flower-like TiO2 and TiO2@C were introduced into MgH2 system using a ball milling method. The result composites were referred to MgH2+fl-TiO2 and MgH2+fl-TiO2@C, respectively. Fig. 3 shows the DSC measurements and TPD tests (Temperature programed desorption) of primitive MgH2, MgH2+fl-TiO2 and MgH2+fl-TiO2@C. It is found that the peak temperature of primitive MgH2 is 362.6 °C. After doping with the as-synthesized TiO2, the peak temperatures are tremendously reduced. The peak temperature of MgH2+fl-TiO2 is 245.4 °C and the peak temperature of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C is further reduced to 233.0 °C. TPD tests were also conducted on these composites. For primitive MgH2, the onset desorption temperature is 294.6 °C and the hydrogen desorption capacity is 7.28 wt%. After doped with fl-TiO2, the onset temperature of hydrogen desorption is dramatically reduced to 199.2 °C and the amount of hydrogen released is about 0.57 wt% lower than primitive MgH2. Meanwhile the addition of fl-TiO2@C can further lower the onset dehydrogenation temperature to 180.3 °C, but the hydrogen desorption capacity shows some increase comparing to MgH2+fl-TiO2 composite. In order to reveal the dehydrogenation kinetics of MgH2+fl-TiO2 and MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composites, isothermal dehydrogenation measurements were conducted at different temperatures (Fig. 4 ). It can be seen that the primitive MgH2 can hardly release any hydrogen at a temperature as low as 250 °C. So the isothermal desorption curve is a horizontal line. And fl-TiO2 and fl-TiO2@C doped MgH2 could almost completely dehydrogen at the same temperature. The catalyst doped MgH2 can release more than 6.5 wt% hydrogen within 20 min. And the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C shows superior desorption kinetics than MgH2+fl-TiO2. MgH2+fl-TiO2@C can release 6.0 wt% in 7 min while the MgH2+fl-TiO2 takes 8 min to release the same amount of hydrogen. As the dehydrogenation temperature goes down, the kinetic difference is much clear. The MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composite can release about 4.9 wt% hydrogen at 225 °C within 60 min while MgH2+fl-TiO2 can release about 3.9 wt% hydrogen within 60 min at the same temperature. When the desorption temperature drops to 200 °C, the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C sample releases about 3.0 wt% hydrogen in 100 min while the MgH2+fl-TiO2 releases about 0.9 wt% hydrogen. Based on the hydrogen desorption results, it is clear that the fl-TiO2@C has better catalytic effect at low temperature. This may be due to the enhanced catalytic effect of carbon in fl-TiO2@C. To further understand the enhancement in the desorption kinetics of MgH2, the activation energy (E a) of dehydrogenation was calculated using the Kissinger method [33] with the equation ln(β/T p 2)= –E a/RT p+ln(AR/E a), where β, T p, A and R are the heating rate, the absolute temperature of the desorption peaks, pre-exponential factor and the gas constant. Fig. 5 shows the DSC curves of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C (a) and MgH2+fl-TiO2 (b) composites at various heating rates. With the increase of heating rate, the peak temperatures of hydrogen release also increase. Then Kissinger fitting lines of the dehydrogenation were obtained (Fig. 5(c)) and the E a was calculated from the slopes of the fitting lines. The activation energy (E a) of MgH2+fl-TiO2 composite is about 77.72 kJ/mol and the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composite is about 67.10 kJ/mol. The E a of primitive MgH2 was calculated to be 187.78 kJ/mol in our previous work [34]. The smaller E a of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C and MgH2+fl-TiO2 can directly prove the better desorption kinetics of MgH2 and fl-TiO2@C composite has more superior effect in the enhancement of MgH2 kinetics. Hydrogen absorption kinetics of MgH2+fl-TiO2 and MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composites were also tested. As shown in Fig. 6 , MgH2+fl-TiO2 and MgH2+fl-TiO2@C can absorb over 6.0 wt% hydrogen at 150 °C and the hydrogenation rate of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composite shows a strong acceleration comparing to the MgH2+fl-TiO2 composite. After hydrogenation at 150 °C for 40 min, the MgH2+fl-TiO2 composite absorbs about 6.0 wt% hydrogen and the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composite can absorb 6.3 wt% hydrogen. The hydrogenation curves of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C at low temperature were also shown in Fig. 6. In the initial stage of hydrogenation, the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C shows great absorption kinetics, and the sorption rate is slower after the first few minutes. After hydrogenation for 40 min, MgH2+fl-TiO2@C can absorb 3.90 wt% at 50 °C or 5.0 wt% hydrogen at 100 °C. Table 1 lists recent works on the hydrogen sorption properties for the catalyzed MgH2 system. Compared with the relevant experimental results, the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composite shows great improvement in the de/rehydrogenation kinetics of MgH2. 3.3 Evolution of MgH2+fl-TiO2@c composite and investigation of the catalytic mechanism To further understand the catalytic mechanism of the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composite, XRD and TEM measurements were conducted. Fig. 7 shows the XRD patterns of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C and MgH2+fl-TiO2 at ball milled state and dehydrogenation state. The primary phase transformation during the hydrogen sorption process is the transformation between Mg and MgH2 and the XRD patterns proved it well. Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 in ball milled state were found at around 25° which can be ascribed to the crystal size in both catalysts. But after dehydrogenation, the diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 disappear which is probably because of the partly reduction of TiO2 [34]. TEM and HRTEM images were also taken for the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composites. Fig. 8 shows the TEM and inserted SAED images of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C. The ball milled samples shows obvious granular shape, and no flower-like particles are observed in the TEM analysis which indicates that the microstructure of flower shape was destroyed during the ball milling process. From the TEM image (Fig. 8(a) and (c)), the ball milled MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composites are about 200–400 nm in size, and after dehydrogenation, the MgH2 particles are about 300–500 nm due to the grain growth. The lattice fringe of MgH2 and Mg can be identified in the HRTEM images before and after dehydrogenation and the same point can be made according to the SAED images. Meanwhile the lattice fringe of anatase and rutile TiO2 can also be identified (Fig. 8(d)) which illustrates the existence of TiO2 in dehydrogenated sample. The existence of TiO2 illustrate that TiO2 could be partly reduced to lower valence state after dehydrogenation and multi-valence of Ti could be also effective in this system. EDX mapping images were also taken to analyze the element distribution of Mg, O, Ti and C (Fig. 9 ). Based on the distribution diagram of each element, it can be seen that the TiO2 and C are distributed evenly on the Mg/MgH2 particles which clearly testify the mixing effect of ball milling. Combining the TEM and EDX results, it can be seen that the ball milling process can completely destroy the flower-like structure of catalyst and create small pieces covered on the surface of Mg/MgH2 particles Combining the above analyses, the great catalyst effect of flower-like TiO2@C in Mg/MgH2 system can be ascribed to the following reasons. First, the pyrolysis treatment of titanium glycerolate precursor could keep the original structure and produce two phases. The flower-like TiO2@C is constituted of numerous rod structure and the phase composition contains two different phases rather than only one phase. This phase composition and unique loose structure will cause great friability of flower-like TiO2 and make it more likely to crumble during the ball milling process. This will tremendously enhance the ball milling effect and make the catalyst to distribute more uniformly on the Mg/MgH2 matrix (Fig. 10 ). Second, the TiO2 in this catalyst will be partly reduced to lower valence during the hydrogen sorption process. The multiple valence of Ti will lead to the weaker bonding between Mg‒H atoms and promote the hydrogen dissociation, resulting in the low activation energy of MgH2 [6,34,37]. Third, as we discussed in our previous work [34], the existence of amorphous carbon can not only prevent the aggregation and growth of catalyst, but also reduce the desorption energy of H in MgH2. 4 Conclusions In summary, a flower-like TiO2@C catalyst was synthesized using a simple and convenient method combining one-step solvothermal process and low-temperature pyrolysis. The as-synthesized flower-like TiO2@C shows efficient catalysis on hydrogen storage properties of MgH2. The onset temperature for hydrogen desorption of MgH2+fl-TiO2@C composite is reduced to 180.3 °C and the peak temperature is reduced to 233.0 °C which is far lower than the desorption temperatures of MgH2 and also lower than that of MgH2+fl-TiO2 composite. Meanwhile, the hydrogen sorption kinetics of MgH2 were enhanced with catalyst addition (fl-TiO2@C and fl-TiO2). The MgH2+fl-TiO2@C shows superior desorption kinetics than MgH2+fl-TiO2. MgH2+fl-TiO2@C can release 6.0 wt% in 7 min while the MgH2+fl-TiO2 takes 8 min to release the same amount of hydrogen. When the desorption temperature drops to 200 °C, the MgH2+fl-TiO2@C releases about 3.0 wt% hydrogen in 100 min while the MgH2+fl-TiO2 releases about 0.9 wt% hydrogen. It is clear that the fl-TiO2@C has better catalytic effect at low temperature. And hydrogen absorption kinetics of MgH2 is also greatly improved by the addition of fl-TiO2@C. The excellent catalytic effect of flower-like TiO2@C can be ascribed to three reasons. First, the unique phase composition and structure of flower-like TiO2@C could greatly enhance the ball milling effect and help the uniform distribution of TiO2 and carbon on Mg/MgH2 matrix. Then, the in-situ formed multiple valance of Ti could lead to the weaker bonding between Mg and H atoms and promote the hydrogen dissociation which will reduce the activation energy of MgH2. Third, the amorphous carbon can not only prevent the aggregation and growth of catalyst, but also reduce the desorption energy of H in MgH2. Declaration of Competing Interest The authors declare no conflict of interest. coredata.dc:description: Magnesium hydride has been seen as a potential material for solid state hydrogen storage, but the kinetics and thermodynamics obstacles have hindered its development and application. Three-dimensional flower-like TiO2@C and TiO2 were synthesized as the catalyst for MgH2 system and great catalytic activities are acquired in the hydrogen sorption properties. Experiments also show that the flower-like TiO2@C is superior to flower-like TiO2 in improving the hydrogen storage properties of MgH2. The hydrogen desorption onset and peak temperatures of flower-like TiO2 doped MgH2 is reduced to 199.2 °C and 245.4 °C, while the primitive MgH2 starts to release hydrogen at 294.6 °C and the rapid dehydrogenation temperature is even as high as 362.6 °C. The onset and peak temperatures of flower-like TiO2@C doped MgH2 are further reduced to 180.3 °C and 233.0 °C. The flower-like TiO2@C doped MgH2 composite can release 6.0 wt% hydrogen at 250 °C within 7 min, and 4.86 wt% hydrogen at 225 °C within 60 min, while flower-like TiO2 doped MgH2 can release 6.0 wt% hydrogen at 250 °C within 8 min, and 3.89 wt% hydrogen at 225 °C within 60 min. Hydrogen absorption kinetics is also improved dramatically. Moreover, compared with primitive MgH2 and the flower-like TiO2 doped MgH2, the activation energy of flower-like TiO2@C doped MgH2 is significantly decreased to 67.10 kJ/mol. All the improvement of hydrogen sorption properties can be ascribed to the flower-like structure and the two-phase coexistence of TiO2 and amorphous carbon. Such phase composition and unique structure are proved to be the critical factor to improve the hydrogen sorption properties of MgH2, which can be considered as the new prospect for improving the kinetics of light-metal hydrogen storage materials.

coredata.dc:title: Superior de/hydrogenation performances of MgH2 catalyzed by 3D flower-like TiO2@C nanostructures
